title: Understanding Initial Conditions
text: Start by identifying the initial amounts of A and B in the reaction mixture. How many moles of A and B are present initially?

title: Setting Up the Reaction Table
text: Create a table to track the changes in moles of A and B as the reaction progresses to equilibrium. Use the initial amounts and the change in moles to find the equilibrium amounts.

title: Using the Equilibrium Constant
text: Recall that the equilibrium constant expression for the reaction A(g)⇌B(g) is $$K=\frac{[B]/[A]}{[B]/[A]}$$. Use this expression to relate the changes in concentration to the equilibrium constant value.

title: Calculating Changes in Concentration
text: Assume that $$x$$ moles of A are converted to B at equilibrium. Express the equilibrium concentrations of A and B in terms of $$x$$ and use the equilibrium constant to solve for $$x$$.

title: Finding Equilibrium Concentrations
text: Once you have solved for $$x$$, substitute it back into the expressions for the equilibrium concentrations of A and B to find their values at equilibrium.
